answer_llm: The course will cover the bare minimum of theory, focusing more on practical applications. The theory will be addressed only on an intuitive level, meaning that while some theoretical concepts will be discussed, there will be very few formulas, mostly emphasizing code instead. For example, the course will not delve into derivations like the gradient update rule for logistic regression but will explain how to use logistic regression and interpret the results.
answer_orig:
The bare minimum. The focus is more on practice, and we'll cover the theory only on the intuitive level.: https://mlbookcamp.com/article/python
For example, we won't derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression (there are other great courses for that), but we'll cover how to use logistic regression and make sense of the results.

answer_llm: To succeed in this course, you should be familiar with the following Python basics: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries and understand what libraries are, how to declare a variable and understand what variables are, and perform important operations related to data analysis. If you're not comfortable with these topics, it is recommended that you read the suggested article and consider taking the "Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis" course from OpenClassrooms.
answer_orig:
Check this article. If you know everything in this article, you know enough. If you don’t, read the article and join the coursIntroduction to Pythone too :)
Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp
You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

question: Is there a guide to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
To configure GPU support for TensorFlow on your Ubuntu machine, follow these steps:

1. **Install Nvidia Drivers**: Download and install the appropriate Nvidia drivers from [Nvidia's website](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).

2. **Install CUDA Toolkit**: You need the CUDA toolkit. You can install it from [Nvidia's CUDA Toolkit Archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive). Make sure to select a version compatible with your TensorFlow installation, such as CUDA 11.x.

3. **Install cuDNN**: Download and install cuDNN from [Nvidia's cuDNN download page](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).

4. **Set Up TensorFlow**: You can install TensorFlow with GPU support by following the installation instructions on TensorFlow's official site. For Linux, refer to the relevant section in the [TensorFlow installation guide](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1). 

5. **Configure Environment Variables**: If needed, you may need to set environment variables related to CUDA as pointed out in some guides, such as using `echo` commands to create environment scripts.

For a detailed walkthrough, you can refer to this article that may be helpful: [Setting up TensorFlow with GPU support on Ubuntu](https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/).

question: Can you direct me to a resource for installing TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
To set up TensorFlow with GPU support on Ubuntu, follow this procedure:

1. Install Nvidia drivers from the official [Nvidia website](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).
2. Install CUDA toolkit version 11.x.x from the [CUDA toolkit archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive).
3. Install cuDNN by downloading it from the [cuDNN download page](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).
4. Ensure you have TensorFlow installed, either by using Anaconda to install the package 'tensorflow-gpu' or by using the TensorFlow installation method described in the official [TensorFlow installation guide](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1).
5. Set environment variables if necessary, and make sure to follow the instructions to configure CUDA for TensorFlow.

For more detailed guidance, you can refer to the article that worked for someone setting this up: [ML Zoomcamp Setup Guide](https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/).

answer_llm:
To join a channel in Slack, follow these steps:

1. Click “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you don't see this option, click “More” to find it.
2. Browse the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to search by channel name or description.
3. Select a channel from the list to view it.
4. Click "Join Channel."

For more detailed information, you can visit the Slack help page: https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel.
